name: Introduction
content:
Introduction

In this course we will learn how to convert python extensions from the Extension Framework V1 to Extension Framework V2.

Requirements

Dynatrace

  • Access to a Dynatrace environment
  • An Activegate that you own, it can be your local laptop, connected to the Dynatrace environment
  • VSCode with the Dynatrace Extensions extension installed
  • Connect your Dynatrace environment to the extension as documented here

Knowledge

For this course, you should be familiar with the following topics:

  • Dynatrace extensions - https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/extend-dynatrace/extensions
  • MINT - https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/extend-dynatrace/extend-metrics/reference/metric-ingestion-protocol
  • Custom Topology and Relationships - https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/extend-dynatrace/extend-topology/custom-topology
  • Unified Analysis Pages - https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/extend-dynatrace/extend-ui/unified-analysis
  • Python development

activityList.name: Extension Framework
activityList.content:
Extension Framework

What is the Extension Framework?

Dynatrace provides ways for us to extend the platform.
When it comes to Extensions, this usually means adding:

  • Metrics
  • Events
  • Charts

For technologies that we do not support OOTB.
This includes JMX and Python Extensions.

Examples of technologies supported via extensions are:

  • IBM MQ
  • Citrix
  • Netscaler
  • Datapower
  • Kafka

We call Extension Framework the set of software components and tooling that allows one to extend the Dynatrace platform via extensions.

Extension Framework V1

The Extension Framework V1, or EF1 (also known as plugins/plugin module/remote plugin module) is a Dynatrace component that can run python extensions in Activegates (remote) and OneAgents (local).

It is primarily composed of:

  • [Remote] Plugin Module - A service that comes with the AG (remote) and OA (local) and can run python extensions.
  • plugin-sdk - A python library that allows you to write, simulate and build python extensions
  • JMX Wizard and JMX Extensions - A tool that allows you to write, and deploy JMX extensions

There are some challenges when it comes to EF1, mainly:

  • Distribution and Scalability - Every extension zip file must be manually placed in the OneAgents or Activegates, they must also be uploaded to the Dynatrace environment.
  • UI Customization - You are limited to adding simple charts to HOSTs, PGIs or Custom Device screens
  • Data types - Only metrics and events are supported
  • Python runtime - A single python runtime is shared between all extensions, making dealing with dependencies, performance and name collisions a challenge
  • Few datasources - Only python and JMX
  • * Other Limitations - Several limits are imposed, like the query method must run every minute, you can only have 100 unique dimensions per metric, only two key metrics, need to define metric metadata before collection, two separate extensions for AG and OA for the same technology, simple extension parameters in the UI, no way to filter which metrics to report, etc.

Extension Framework V2

The Extension Framework V2 (EF2) addresses many of the issues with EF1, in it's core is the Extensions Execution Controller (EEC), which replaces the former plugin module.

Issues EF1 EF2
Distribution Manual distribution Automatically deploys to AGs and OAs
Scalability Single Activegate assigned to an endpoint Activegate groups, Host groups, Tags, load balancing
UI Customization Simple charts and Custom Devices Custom Topology, Unified Analysis Screens
Data types Metrics and events Metrics, events, logs
Python runtime Shared interpreter and environment between extensions Unique interpreter and environment for each extension
Datasources Python and JMX Python, JMX, SQL, WMI, SNMP, SNMP Traps, Prometheus

The EEC is a service installed with the Activegate and the OneAgent, and provides low level mechanisms to run extensions and communicate with Dynatrace. You can see the EEC running in your hosts as "extensionsmodule[.exe]" for the AG and "oneagent_extensions[.exe]" for the OA.

The EEC can run datasources, which are programs that support different types of extensions. These datasource come bundled with the AG and OA.

Most of these datasources are declarative, meaning you only need to provide a yaml file that describes which metrics, events, screens, topology you want your extension to create and collect, and no coding is required at all.

These declarative datasources are (as of today):

  • SQL - Can query databases. (AG only)
  • WMI - Can query Windows machines using WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation) queries. (Windows OA and AGs only)
  • SNMP - Can query SNMP devices (AG only)
  • SNMP Traps - Can listen for SNMP traps (AG only)
  • Prometheus - Can scrape prometheus metrics (server and exporters) (AG and OA)
  • JMX - Can obtain JMX metrics from an OneAgent monitored JVM. (OA only)

Under the hood this is implemented via programming languages datasources, which are developed and maintained by R&D. These datasources can be expanded in the future, to provide declarative support for new technologies.

  • Java datasource : SQL
  • Go datasource: SNMP, SNMP Traps, Prometheus and WMI

Still, we need a way to let developers (extensions team, services, partners, customers) to write coded extensions, not everything can be done declaratively, and R&D cannot cover every use case and technology in the market.

This is why the EEC also supports the Python datasource.
This datasource allows you to write python extensions, which are python modules that can run custom python code from Activegates and OneAgents.

From now on, we will focus on the Python datasource and how to convert custom python extensions from EF1 to EF2.

name: Converting Python Extensions
content:
Converting Python Extensions

High level overview

Here is how EF1 python extensions components map to EF2 python extensions components:

Description EF1 EF2
Metadata, version, screens, topology plugin.json extension.yaml
Extension parametes (like usernames, urls, passwords) plugin.json activationSchema.json
Development file to simulate extension parameters properties.json activation.json
Python library to write, simulate and build python extensions plugin-sdk dt-extensions-sdk
Dependencies plugin.json setup.py
Artifact extension zip file signed extension zip file
Extension code a python class in a .py file standalone python module

So, in a high level view, the steps to convert an EF1 python extension to EF2 are:

  1. Convert the plugin.json file to extension.yaml and activationSchema.json
  2. Create a python extension with dt-extensions-sdk, and move the code from the .py file to the __main__.py file
  3. Build and sign the extension

activityList.name: Structure of a python extension
activityList.content:
Structure of a python extension

In this section we will explore some of the differences between the structure of an EF1 and an EF2 python extension.

Project structure

Let's observe the differences between the folder structure of an EF1 and an EF2 python extension:

  • EF1

  • EF2

Even though there are more files in the Extension EF2, the structure makes more sense and it is more modular.
The advantages of such structure are:

  1. The extension is a standalone python module. It can run on it's own and generates a python wheel file when built.
  2. The parameters are separated from metadata. (Paramaters are almost always mandatory, metadata is optional and can be defined elsewhere)

SDK installation

Every extension needs to use the Python SDK, both for development and during the runtime.

To install the python SDK for EF1, the steps were:

  1. Download the SDK zip file from Dynatrace, Settings > Monitored technologies > Add Activegate Extension > Download Extension SDK
  2. Extract the wheel file out of the SDK zip file
  3. Install the wheel file with something like pip install D:\tmp\plugin_sdk-1.279.60.20231102.112406-py3-none-any.whl

For EF2, the only step is:

  1. pip install dt-extensions-sdk[cli]

Note: always use a python virtual environment when installing python libraries.

One can be created with 

python -m venv venv
# Then, on windows:
.\venv\Scripts\activate

# Or, on linux:
source venv/bin/activate

Project creation

To create an EF1 extension, you need to manually create the extension files, usually by copying from some other extension.

To create an EF2 extension, you can use the SDK:

dt-sdk create

Running the extension

To run an EF1 extension:

plugin_sdk simulate_plugin
# or oneagent_sim
# or oneagent_simulate_plugin

To run an EF2 extension:

dt-sdk run

Building the extension

To build an EF1 extension:

plugin_sdk build_plugin
# or oneagent_build_plugin

To build (and sign) an EF2 extension:

dt-sdk build

Uploading the extension

To upload an EF1 extension:

plugin_sdk upload_plugin

To upload an EF2 extension:

dt-sdk upload

activityList.name: Code differences
activityList.content:
Code differences

Extension Class

Note the similarities between the next code examples:

  • They are both a class that extends some Extension class.
  • They both have methods to report metrics and events
  • They both implement the query method, which runs every minute
  • They both implement the initialize method, which runs once when the extension starts

This is a typical EF1 extension:

from ruxit.api.base_plugin import RemoteBasePlugin
from ruxit.api.selectors import ExplicitSelector, EntityType

# Note how this extends RemoteBasePlugin (this extension can only run on an Activegate)
class RabbitMQExtension(RemoteBasePlugin):

    # Optional method to initialize data before running the extension
    def initialize(self, **kwargs):
        self.executions = -1

    def query(self, **kwargs) -> None:
        # Logging to the extension log
        self.logger.info("Started the query method")

        # Obtaining user defined parameters
        node_address = self.config.get("rabbit_mq_node", "localhost")
        username = self.config.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
        password = self.config.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")

        # Creating a custom device (not needed in EF2)
        group = self.topology_builder.create_group("Rabbit MQ Group", "Rabbit MQ Group")
        device = group.create_device(f"RabbitMQ Node {node_address}")

        # Reporting an event
        self.results_builder.report_custom_info_event(error_message,
         "RabbitMQ connection issue with one node",
         entity_selector=ExplicitSelector(group.id, EntityType.CUSTOM_DEVICE_GROUP)) 

        # Reporting a metric
        device.absolute("my.metric", 1, {"device_name": "My Device"})

This is the same extension on EF2:

from dynatrace_extension import Extension
from dynatrace_extension.sdk.event import Severity

# The base class is always the same, this can run on an Activegate or OneAgent
class ExtensionImpl(Extension):

    # Optional method to initialize data before running the extension
    def initialize(self):
        self.executions = -1

    def query(self):
        # Logging to the extension log
        self.logger.info("Started the query method")

        # Obtaining user defined parameters
        node_address = self.activation_config.get("rabbit_mq_node", "localhost")
        username = self.activation_config.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
        password = self.activation_config.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")

        # Reporting an event
        self.report_dt_event(Severity.INFO, "RabbitMQ connection issue with one node")

        # Reporting a metric
        self.report_metric("my.metric", 1, {"device_name": "My Device"})


def main():
    ExtensionImpl().run()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

Quick method Reference

The methods are quite similar, the SDK was written with developer experience in mind.
Here is a table of the most common methods and their EF1 and EF2 counterparts:

Description EF1 method EF2 method Notes
Logging self.logger.info("message") self.logger.info("message") Stays the same
Obtaining user defined parameters self.config.get("param_name", "default_value") self.activation_config.get("param_name", "default_value") You can find and replace all self.config. entries with self.activation_config.
Report an event self.results_builder.report_custom_info_event self.report_dt_event Try to keep topology (groups, device, IDs) out of the code, this is defined later in the extension.yaml file.
Report a metric device.absolute("metric_key", metric_value, {"dimension_name": "dimension_value"}) self.report_metric("metric_key", metric_value, {"dimension_name": "dimension_value"}) There is no concept of a device in the python code anymore, send metrics directly.
Create groups and custom devices self.topology_builder.create_group, group.create_device n/a Doesn't exist, topology is defined in the extension.yaml file.

The EF2 SDK also provides many other methods that are not available in EF1:

Description Method
Report a log event self.report_log_event
Report multiple log events self.report_log_events
Report multiple log lines self.report_log_lines
Report multiple metrics self.report_mint_lines
Schedule a method to run periodically self.schedule

Please check the documentation [here](TODO: LINK TO DOCS)

activityList.name: Metadata differences
activityList.content:
Metadata differences

There are three main metadata components in an extension:

  • Name, entrypoint, version, metrics, charts
  • Dependencies (python libraries that your code needs)
  • Extension parameters (user defined)

Extension name, entrypoint, version, metrics, charts

In EF1, these were in plugin.json, example:

{
  "name": "custom.remote.python.rabbit_mq",
  "version": "1.0.1",
  "metricGroup": "tech.RabbitMQ",
  "technologies": ["RabbitMQ"],
  "type": "python",
  "entity": "CUSTOM_DEVICE",
  "source": {
    "package": "rabbitmq_extension",
    "className": "RabbitMQExtension",
    "install_requires": []
  },
  "metrics": [
    {"timeseries": {"key": "messages_ready", "unit": "Count", "dimensions": ["Queue", "VirtualHost"],"displayname": "Messages Ready"}},
    {"timeseries": {"key": "messages_unacknowledged", "unit": "Count", "dimensions": ["Queue", "VirtualHost"],"displayname": "Messages Unacknowledged"}}
  ],
  "ui": {
    "charts": [
    {"group": "Messages", "title": "Message rates", "series":  [
      {"key": "messages_ack", "displayname": "Acknowledge"},
      {"key": "messages_deliver_get", "displayname": "Deliver Get"},
    ]},
    {"group": "Messages", "title": "Messages", "series":  [
      {"key": "messages_ready", "displayname": "Ready"},
      {"key": "messages_unacknowledged", "displayname": "Unacknowledged"}
    ]}
  ]}
}

In EF2, these are in extension.yaml, example:

name: com.dynatrace.mulesoft-cloudhub
version: 1.1.22
minDynatraceVersion: "1.256"
author:
  name: Dynatrace

# Python datasource entrypoint (module name and settings 2.0 UI file)
python:
  runtime:
    module: mulesoft_cloudhub
    version:
      min: "3.9"
  activation:
    remote:
      path: activationSchema.json

# These are completely optional
metrics:
  - key: cloudhub.app.requests
    metadata:
      displayName: Inbound Requests
      description: The number of inbound requests for this application
      unit: Count
      sourceEntityType: cloudhub:app
      tags:
        - custom:mulesoft-cloudhub
  - key: cloudhub.app.errors
    metadata:
      displayName: Errors
      description: The number of errors for this application
      unit: Count
      sourceEntityType: cloudhub:app
      tags:
        - custom:mulesoft-cloudhub

# These are also optional, and powerful
screens:
  - entityType: cloudhub:org
    # // Rest of the screen definition

Dependencies

In EF1 they were also part of the plugin.json file, under source/install_requires

In EF2 they are in setup.py, example:

from setuptools import setup, find_packages

setup(name="salesforce_extension",
      version="1.0.0",
      description="Salesforce Extension for Dynatrace",
      author="Dynatrace",
      packages=find_packages(),
      python_requires=">=3.10",
      include_package_data=True,
      install_requires=["dt-extensions-sdk", "requests"],
      extras_require={"dev": ["dt-extensions-sdk[cli]"]},
      )

Extension parameters

In EF1 they were also part of the plugin.json file, under two different keys:

{
    "properties": [
        {"key": "rabbitmq_nodes", "type": "Textarea"},
        {"key": "rabbitmq_username", "type": "String", "defaultValue": "guest"},
        {"key": "rabbitmq_password", "type": "Password"}
    ],
    "configUI": {
        "displayName": "RabbitMQ",
        "properties": [
            {"key": "rabbitmq_nodes", "displayName": "RabbitMQ Nodes", "displayHint": "One url per line.", "displayOrder": 1},
            {"key": "rabbitmq_username", "displayName": "RabbitMQ User", "displayOrder": 2},
            {"key": "rabbitmq_password", "displayName": "RabbitMQ Password", "displayOrder": 3}
        ]
    }
}

In EF2 we leverage Settings 2.0, a much more powerful and customizable UI experience.
It is more verbose as well, but it is worth it.
Extensions come with a pre-configured UI with fields for a URL, username and password, but you can customize it to your needs. 

{
    "authentication": {
      "type": "object",
      "displayName": "Authentication",
      "properties": {
        "authentication_type": {
          "displayName": "Authentication type",
          "type": {
            "$ref": "#/enums/authentication_type"
          },
          "nullable": false,
          "default": "username_password",
          "maxObjects": 1,
          "modificationPolicy": "DEFAULT"
        },
        "username": {
          "displayName": "Username",
          "documentation": "The user must have the permissions:\n\n ### **General User Permissions**\n\n* `View Real-Time Event Monitoring Data`\n\n### **Administrative Permissions**\n\n* `Customize Application`\n\n* `View All Data`",
          "type": "text",
          "nullable": false,
          "default": "",
          "constraints": [
            {
              "type": "NOT_EMPTY",
              "customMessage": "The Username must not be empty"
            }
          ],
          "precondition": {
            "type": "EQUALS",
            "property": "authentication_type",
            "expectedValue": "username_password"
          }
        },
        "password": {
          "displayName": "Password",
          "type": "secret",
          "nullable": false,
          "default": "",
          "constraints": [
            {
              "type": "NOT_EMPTY",
              "customMessage": "The Password must not be empty"
            }
          ],
          "precondition": {
            "type": "EQUALS",
            "property": "authentication_type",
            "expectedValue": "username_password"
          }
        }
      }
    }
}

If you are inside the Dynatrace VPN, you can access Settings 2.0 documentation and a playground:

  • Documentation: /ui/docs/settings-ui-docs/list
  • Playgrouynd: /ui/docs/settings-playground

The playground is quite useful to test your settings UI, and you can also copy ideas from other Dynatrace settings UIs.

name: Migrating a real extension
content:
Migrating a real extension

In this lab we will migrate an Activegate extension step by step.
We will:

  1. Learn how to create a new python extension on the EF2 framework.
  2. Migrate the plugin.json and extension code to the EF2 extension.
  3. Build, sign, deploy and test our extension.
  4. Create topology and screens

activityList.name: Create a new extension
activityList.content:
Create a new extension

There are two ways of creating a new python extension.

  • Manually via the command line
  • Using our VSCode extension

Both of these methods use the dt-extensions-sdk package.

Install the Python Extensions SDK

pip install dt-extensions-sdk[cli]

pip install dt-extensions-sdk[cli]

Note: In some shells like zsh, you may need to escape the brackets like this: pip install dt-extensions-sdk\[cli\]

Important:

Always use a python virtual environment for every extension project you have.
This will ensure that you have the correct dependencies installed for each project.
It will also guarantee that your system's python is not polluted with dependencies that you don't need.
You can install dt-extensions-sdk[cli] globally, but you should never install your extension's dependencies globally.

On Windows, this can be done with:

python -m venv venv; .\venv\Scripts\activate

On Linux/MacOS, this can be done with:

python -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate

VSCode extension

For this option you still need to have python and the dt-extensions-sdk installed.

Install our VSCode extension (Extensions > Search for Dynatrace Extensions > Install)

Open an empty folder and run the Dynatrace extensions: Initialize workspace command.

  • Choose the latest available schema version
  • Create or use an existing certificate
  • Choose the project type "Python Extension 2.0"
  • Give the extension a name

Command Line

  1. Create certificates
dt-sdk gencerts
  1. Create a new extension
dt-sdk create my_first_extension

Simulating

  1. Change directory to the new extension
cd my_first_extension
  1. Run the extension
dt-sdk run

Deploying

  1. Build the extension
dt-sdk build
# If using the vscode extension, use F1 -> Dynatrace extensions: Build
  1. Upload the extension
dt-sdk upload
# If using the vscode extension, you get prompted to upload after building

Note, to upload from the command line you have two options:

  1. Set environment variables (recommended):
  • DT_API_URL - Your Dynatrace tenant URL
  • DT_API_TOKEN - Your Dynatrace API token
  1. Pass these as arguments to dt-sdk upload

Note that every dt-sdk command can be explained with the --help flag:

activityList.name: Plugin.json migration
activityList.content:
Plugin.json migration

The plugin.json contains some important metadata we want to migrate.
Some of it, like the extension version, dependencies and even metric descriptions are easy to migrate to the extension.yaml file.
On the other hand, migrating the properties to the new Settings 2.0 properties format can take a while to get used to.

To solve the problem of migrating the properties section, we have added a feature to the VSCode extension that can help you automatically create the activationSchema.json file.

Dynatrace extensions: Convert Python

On VSCode, press F1 (or Ctrl + Shift + P) and search for Dynatrace extensions: Convert Python.

This allows you to convert an existing extension, you have a couple of options:

  • Import an extension zip file from your computer
  • Import a plugin.json file from your computer
  • Import an extension directly from your Dynatrace Environment

In our case, we are migrating an existing extension from the filesystem, so we will choose the Locally option.
Find the file custom.remote.python.rabbit_mq.zip and chose it to be imported.

After you chose an option, and the file/extension to import, you will be either:

  1. Asked where to save the newly generated activationSchema.json file (if you don't have an EF2 extension workspace opened); or
  2. Have the activationSchema.json written for you (if you have an EF2 extension workspace opened)

We should already have our workspace opened, so the activationSchema.json file will be written for us.
Let us explore the code.

Under types, we have the type custom_extension, which has the following properties.
Node that these were extracted automatically from the plugin.json file. We are free to modify them as we see fit. 

{
    "rabbitmq_node": {
        "displayName": "RabbitMQ Node",
        "type": "text",
        "description": "The rabbitmq management URL http://my.host:15672",
        "nullable": true,
        "subType": "multiline"
    },
    "rabbitmq_username": {
        "displayName": "RabbitMQ User",
        "type": "text",
        "description": "",
        "nullable": false,
        "default": "guest"
    },
    "rabbitmq_password": {
        "displayName": "RabbitMQ Password",
        "type": "secret",
        "description": "",
        "nullable": true
    },
    "queues_include": {
        "displayName": "Queues to include",
        "type": "text",
        "description": "One regex expression per line, use .* to monitor all",
        "nullable": false,
        "default": ".*",
        "subType": "multiline"
    },
    "frequency": {
        "displayName": "Frequency (minutes)",
        "type": "integer",
        "description": "",
        "nullable": false,
        "default": 1
    }
}

We also have a type called pythonRemote
This could have been called anything, we use it to declare a list of endpoints, which are a list of custom_extension types (the one from above)
We can also modify the displayName and other metadata about this, like allowing a single endpoint per monitoring configuration instead of 100. 

{
    "type": "object",
    "displayName": "Python Remote Extension",
    "properties": {
    "endpoints": {
        "displayName": "Endpoint",
        "type": "list",
        "items": {
        "type": {
            "$ref": "#/types/custom_extension"
        }
        },
        "nullable": false,
        "minItems": 1,
        "maxItems": 100,
        "metaData": {
        "addItemButton": "Add endpoint"
        }
    }
    }
}

Finally, under properties we have a single property called pythonRemote.
This is a mandatory property for remote (activegate) extensions. For OneAgents this would be pythonLocal.
Note that you can also declare both on the same extension, if you want to support both Activegates and OneAgents. 

{
    "properties": {
    "pythonRemote": {
      "displayName": "Python Remote Extension",
      "type": {
        "$ref": "#/types/pythonRemote"
        }
      }
    }
}

If you want to learn more about this settings file, please research Settings 2.0 internally in Dynatrace.
When you are on the VPN and have access as Devops Viewer, you can navigate to these URLs for the documentation and a playground in your Dynatrace environment:

/ui/docs/settings-ui-docs
/ui/docs/settings-playground

Change extension.yaml

Since this is a remote extension, we should change our extension.yaml file, removing the activation > local entry, so that our extension can only run on Activegates.
You can comment or delete the lines. Please realize how you could even have different activationSchema.json files for different activation types. 

name: custom:rabbitmq-extension
version: 0.0.1
minDynatraceVersion: "1.253"
author:
  name: "Dynatrace"

python:
  runtime:
    module: rabbitmq_extension
    version:
      min: "3.9"

  activation:
    remote:
      path: activationSchema.json
    # local:
    #   path: activationSchema.json

Build and activate

To test that our settings 2.0 works as expected, let's build and activate our extension.
Fron the VSCode command palette, run the Dynatrace extensions: Build command and accept the prompts to upload the extension to Dynatrace.

Navigate to Dynatrace, and create a new monitoring configuration for our extension.

You should see a screen similar to this one:

We can copy the value from the JSON snippet on the right side and adapt it to our RabbitMQ instance:

{
    "enabled": true,
    "description": "",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "pythonRemote": {
      "endpoints": [
        {
          "rabbitmq_node": "https://b-d9835915-0721-47f1-994c-b43c7b6dd800.mq.us-east-1.amazonaws.com",
          "rabbitmq_username": "dynatrace",
          "rabbitmq_password": "password",
          "queues_include": ".*",
          "frequency": 1
        }
      ]
    }
}

Paste this content into the activation.json file, and save it.

activityList.name: Code migration
activityList.content:
Code migration

The code migration is a bit manual for now. We are working on automating this further.

A reminder of the most important changes:

Description EF1 method EF2 method Notes
Logging self.logger.info("message") self.logger.info("message") Stays the same
Obtaining user defined parameters self.config.get("param_name", "default_value") self.activation_config.get("param_name", "default_value") You can find and replace all self.config. entries with self.activation_config.
Report an event self.results_builder.report_custom_info_event self.report_dt_event Try to keep topology (groups, device, IDs) out of the code, this is defined later in the extension.yaml file.
Report a metric device.absolute("metric_key", metric_value, {"dimension_name": "dimension_value"}) self.report_metric("metric_key", metric_value, {"dimension_name": "dimension_value"}) There is no concept of a device in the python code anymore, send metrics directly.
Create groups and custom devices self.topology_builder.create_group, group.create_device n/a Doesn't exist, topology is defined in the extension.yaml file.

RabbitMQ Code Migration

Let's look at the existing extension code, and annotate the changes we need to make. 

import re
from typing import Dict


# TODO - These imports no longer exist, we can remove them
# The editor will tell us what broke
from ruxit.api.base_plugin import RemoteBasePlugin
from ruxit.api.selectors import ExplicitSelector, EntityType
from ruxit.api.topology_builder import Device

from rabbitmq_api import RabbitMQClient


# TODO - This class can stay, but it will inherit from Extension instead of RemoteBasePlugin
class RabbitMQExtension(RemoteBasePlugin):

    # This can stay, although it is not necessary to count executions anymore
    def initialize(self, **kwargs):
        self.executions = -1

    # This can also stay!
    def query(self, **kwargs) -> None:
        self.executions += 1

        # Step 1 - Get configuration parameters from the UI
        # TODO - We get a list of endpoints, so we need a for loop here.
        # TODO - Replace self.config with self.activation_config
        node_address = self.config.get("rabbitmq_node", "")
        username = self.config.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
        password = self.config.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")
        queues_include = self.config.get("queues_include", ".*").split("/n")
        frequency = self.config.get("frequency", 1)

        # The user can choose the frequency of the plugin execution
        # We need this workaround (counting the number of times the query method is executed)
        # NOTE - We can ask the frequency directly to the user in EF2
        if self.executions % frequency == 0:

            # This is topology, create a CUSTOM_DEVICE_GROUP
            # TODO - Remove this
            group = self.topology_builder.create_group("Rabbit MQ Group", "Rabbit MQ Group")

            # This is a check, we are trying to connect to RabbitMQ
            rabbit = RabbitMQClient(node_address, username, password, logger=self.logger)
            try:
                _ = rabbit.cluster
                self.logger.info(f"Successfully connected to {node_address}")
            except Exception as e:
                error_message = f"Could not connect to RabbitMQ node {node_address}"

                # TODO - Replace this with self.report_dt_event
                self.results_builder.report_error_event(error_message, "RabbitMQ connection issue", entity_selector=ExplicitSelector(group.id, EntityType.CUSTOM_DEVICE_GROUP))
                self.logger.error(error_message)
                raise Exception(error_message) from e

            # This is also topology, we need to create CUSTOM_DEVICE manually
            # TODO - Remove this
            nodes: Dict[str, Device] = {}
            for node in rabbit.nodes:
                nodes[node.name] = group.create_device(f"RabbitMQ Node {node.name}")

            # Report the queue metrics
            for queue in rabbit.queues:
                self.logger.info(f"Checking queue '{queue.name}'")
                monitor = False

                for pattern in queues_include:
                    if pattern and re.match(pattern, queue.name):
                        self.logger.info(f"Adding queue '{queue.name}' because it matched the pattern '{pattern}'")
                        monitor = True

                if monitor: 
                    # TODO - We don't need to use the device anymore
                    device = nodes.get(queue.node)

                    # TODO - Replace these with self.report_metric
                    device.absolute("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
                    device.absolute("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})

# TODO - At the very end we have to call the main method 
# This should already be present in the EF2 code

Fixing errors

Start by copying the entire EF1 class and overwriting the code in the __main__.py file.
Keep the last lines which run the extension.

You should receive some errors and warnings from the editor, and we will fix them one by one.

Imports

Our code depends on a file called rabbitmq_api.py, which is not present in the EF2 extension.
Copy that file to the same directory as the __main__.py file. Since this file has no dependencies, it should work as is.

There are several ruxit dependencies from the framework V1, you can always remove them all, delete all lines that start with from ruxit.

All extensions extend from the Extension class, let's import that class and update the class definition.
We also should import rabbitmq_api with a relative import using a ., we are a module now and not a standalone file. 

import re
from typing import Dict

from dynatrace_extension import Extension # We added this line

from .rabbitmq_api import RabbitMQClient # We changed this line

class RabbitMQExtension(Extension): # We changed this line

    def initialize(self, **kwargs):
        self.executions = -1

Try to run the extension now, the error output will tell us what is wrong.

Change the main definition, the class name is RabbitMQExtension.

Note, you could have also changed the class name to be ExtensionImpl, it doesn't affect the extension. 

def main():
    RabbitMQExtension().run()

Highlighting errors

You have a couple of options to highlight the errors in the code.

  1. Run dt-sdk run

This will run the extension and highlight the errors in the code, only if they raise an Exception.

  1. Install a linter, like Pylint or Ruff

They will point out errors in the code, and are a bit more strict than the dt-sdk run command.
These tools do code analysis, and let us know of things that are incorrect, example:

Note that these tools will also suggest some code changes that we might not agree with or don't care right now.
You can ignore the warning and information messages, and focus on the errors.

The Problems tab in vscode should also show the errors.

I suggest starting with PyLint, install the PyLint extension in VSCode.

Fixing endpoints

In EF1, every execution of the query method happened in a single endpoint.
In EF2 you have freedom to decide how the user can configure the extension.
For instance, they can monitor multiple RabbitMQ servers in a single monitoring configuration.
Our extension allows up to 100 endpoints, so we need to loop through the endpoint configurations.

Add a line to obtain the endpoints, and then loop through them.
Replace the self.config with the endpoint instances.
If you are confused as to why this is needed, this comes from what we defined in the activationSchema.json file. 

 def query(self, **kwargs) -> None:
        self.executions += 1

        endpoints = self.activation_config.get("endpoints")
        for endpoint in endpoints:

            # Step 1 - Get configuration parameters from the UI
            node_address = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_node", "")
            username = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
            password = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")
            queues_include = endpoint.get("queues_include", ".*").split("/n")
            frequency = endpoint.get("frequency", 1)

Remember, you could also have chosen to only allow a single endpoint, this is up to the developer to decide.

Remove topology (groups and devices)

All the topology in EF2 is declared from metric lines.
This means we don't create devices and groups in the code.

Remove the line that creates a group, and update the event reporting to use the self.report_dt_event method. 

    if self.executions % frequency == 0:

        # Removed this line
        # group = self.topology_builder.create_group("Rabbit MQ Group", "Rabbit MQ Group")

        # This is a check, we are trying to connect to RabbitMQ
        rabbit = RabbitMQClient(node_address, username, password, logger=self.logger)
        try:
            _ = rabbit.cluster
            self.logger.info(f"Successfully connected to {node_address}")
        except Exception as e:
            error_message = f"Could not connect to RabbitMQ node {node_address}"

            # Remove this line
            #  # self.results_builder.report_error_event(error_message, "RabbitMQ connection issue", entity_selector=ExplicitSelector(group.id, EntityType.CUSTOM_DEVICE_GROUP))
            self.report_dt_event(DtEventType.ERROR_EVENT, error_message) # Replace it with this line

            self.logger.error(error_message)
            raise Exception(error_message) from e

For this code to work, import the DtEventType enum from the dynatrace_extension module. 

from dynatrace_extension import Extension

from dynatrace_extension.sdk.extension import DtEventType

We don't need to create Custom Devices anymore, so this loop can be removed altogether:

    # This is also topology, we need to create CUSTOM_DEVICE manually
    nodes: Dict[str, Device] = {}
    for node in rabbit.nodes:
        nodes[node.name] = group.create_device(f"RabbitMQ Node {node.name}")

Fix metric reporting

Finally, we don't need a custom device to report metrics, so the metric reporting code will change:

if monitor:
    device = nodes.get(queue.node)
    device.absolute("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})
    device.absolute("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"VirtualHost": queue.vhost, "Queue": queue.name})

Becomes:

if monitor:
    self.report_metric("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
    self.report_metric("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})

Note, dimension keys must be lowercase in MINT.
With all these changes, the code should look something like this:

import re
from typing import Dict

from dynatrace_extension import Extension
from dynatrace_extension.sdk.extension import DtEventType

from .rabbitmq_api import RabbitMQClient

class RabbitMQExtension(Extension):

    def initialize(self, **kwargs):
        self.executions = -1

    def query(self, **kwargs) -> None:
        self.executions += 1

        endpoints = self.activation_config.get("endpoints")
        for endpoint in endpoints:

            # Step 1 - Get configuration parameters from the UI
            node_address = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_node", "")
            username = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
            password = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")
            queues_include = endpoint.get("queues_include", ".*").split("/n")
            frequency = endpoint.get("frequency", 1)

            # The user can choose the frequency of the plugin execution
            # We need this workaround (counting the number of times the query method is executed)
            if self.executions % frequency == 0:

                # This is topology, create a CUSTOM_DEVICE_GROUP
                # group = self.topology_builder.create_group("Rabbit MQ Group", "Rabbit MQ Group")

                # This is a check, we are trying to connect to RabbitMQ
                rabbit = RabbitMQClient(node_address, username, password, logger=self.logger)
                try:
                    _ = rabbit.cluster
                    self.logger.info(f"Successfully connected to {node_address}")
                except Exception as e:
                    error_message = f"Could not connect to RabbitMQ node {node_address}"
                    self.report_dt_event(DtEventType.ERROR_EVENT, error_message)
                    self.logger.error(error_message)
                    raise Exception(error_message) from e

                # Report the queue metrics
                for queue in rabbit.queues:
                    self.logger.info(f"Checking queue '{queue.name}'")
                    monitor = False

                    for pattern in queues_include:
                        if pattern and re.match(pattern, queue.name):
                            self.logger.info(f"Adding queue '{queue.name}' because it matched the pattern '{pattern}'")
                            monitor = True

                    if monitor:
                        self.report_metric("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                        self.report_metric("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})


def main():
    RabbitMQExtension().run()



if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

Running the extension should give us an unauthorized error, since we are using the default credentials.

Fixing the password in the activation.json file should fix the error.

Migrating dependencies

Our code has a dependency on the requests library.
In EF1 some third party libraries came included with the Remote Plugin Module, in EF2 this is no longer the case.
Edit the setup.py file and add the requests library to the install_requires list. 

from setuptools import setup, find_packages

setup(name="rabbitmq_extension",
      version="0.0.1",
      description="Rabbitmq_extension python EF2 extension",
      author="Dynatrace",
      packages=find_packages(),
      python_requires=">=3.10",
      include_package_data=True,
      install_requires=["dt-extensions-sdk", "requests"],
      extras_require={"dev": ["dt-extensions-sdk[cli]"]},
      )

We should now be able to build the extension and upload it to Dynatrace.
The Build command automatically increases the version number, so we don't need to change it.
Remember that you could also do this manually, by running the command dt-sdk build in the terminal.

To actually deploy this to an Activegate:

Deploy the extension

  1. Make sure that the Activegate trusts your certificate.
  2. Create a monitoring configuration for the extension.

There are some nice tips on troubleshooting python extensions here

If you don't have the root certificate present in the Activegate, you will get error messages like this in the EEC extensions logs:

2024-01-03 01:44:59.860 UTC [0000d5fc] info    [native] Rejected fastcheck for task f_2575433908796020679 - Extension not found in cache. Reason: Extension custom:rabbitmq-extension(0.0.2) not available in cache yet (queued for download). Next retry in <1 minutes
2024-01-03 01:45:03.150 UTC [0000b2d4] info    [native] Downloaded custom:rabbitmq-extension 0.0.2 550fd37f01d887404f85af391419d62846f5c639988181e1bac5acb3795d4ee9
2024-01-03 01:45:03.150 UTC [0000b2d4] warning [native] SignatureVerifier: Unable to verify C:\ProgramData\dynatrace\remotepluginmodule\/agent/runtime\extensions\download\custom_rabbitmq-extension
2024-01-03 01:45:03.150 UTC [0000b2d4] info    [native] SignatureVerified: avaiable certificate files: cacert.pem, ca.pem
2024-01-03 01:45:03.150 UTC [0000b2d4] warning [native] SignatureVerifier: openssl error: error:2E099064:CMS routines:cms_signerinfo_verify_cert:certificate verify error : Verify error:unable to get local issuer certificate

You can also see these logs directly in Dynatrace:

If everything is working, you should see metrics in Dynatrace after a couple of minutes:

These are a bit dull, just metrics without entities and screens, we will fix that next.

activityList.name: Topology
activityList.content:
Topology

This course does not intend to go in depth about topology in Dynatrace.
There is documentation about topology here

The important bits to know for this exercise are:

  1. There are no more pure Custom Devices, every entity can have it's own type.
  2. Entities are not created in the code, they are always derived from metrics (or logs, events and spans)
  3. There can be relationships between entities, example: a queue runs on a virtual host.

Defining topology

We have two entity types we can create for our extension:

  • Virtual Host, queues always belong to a virtual host.
  • Queue

Always think about how the topology can be shaped from metrics when creating an extension.

Topology definition is not tied to python extensions, any extension can define topology and it is unrelated to metric collection.
Remember that you can always download any extensions from the Dynatrace Hub and look at how they define topology.

Topology - Virtual Host

Let's start by adding the virtual host type, add the topology element to extension.yaml

topology:
  types:
    - name: rabbitmq:vhost
      displayName: Virtual Host
      rules:
        - idPattern: 'rabbitmq:vhost_{virtual_host}'
          instanceNamePattern: '{virtual_host}'
          iconPattern: server
          sources:
            - sourceType: Metrics
              condition: $prefix(messages_)
          requiredDimensions:
            - key: virtual_host

This is telling Dynatrace:

  1. Create a new entity type with ID rabbitmq:vhost and name Virtual Host
  2. Create entities out of this type when the metric prefix is messages_, and there is a dimension virtual_host
  3. Call these entities rabbitmq:vhost_{virtual_host} and display them as {virtual_host}

Building and upload the extension should add this definition to Dynatrace.
Note that this is something that could also have been defined in the Dynatrace UI:

When you navigate to /ui/entity/list/rabbitmq:vhost, you get a list of all virtual hosts that have been created.
Note, this screen can be fully customized with Unified Analysis Screens.

The details screen of an entity can also be customized, by default all metrics are shown.

Topology - Queue

Let's add the queue type by adding an extra item to the types list: 

    - name: rabbitmq:queue
      displayName: Queue
      rules:
        - idPattern: 'rabbitmq:queue_{virtual_host}_{queue}'
          instanceNamePattern: '{queue}'
          iconPattern: queue
          sources:
            - sourceType: Metrics
              condition: $prefix(messages_)
          requiredDimensions:
            - key: queue
            - key: virtual_host

Topology - Relationships

The queue needs to have a relationship to the virtual host.
We can say that a Queue runs on a Virtual Host.

Add the relationships property to the topology section: 

  relationships:
    - sources:
        - sourceType: Metrics
          condition: $prefix(messages_)
      fromType: rabbitmq:queue
      typeOfRelation: RUNS_ON
      toType: rabbitmq:vhost

The entire topology section should now look like this:

topology:
  types:
    - name: rabbitmq:vhost
      displayName: Virtual Host
      rules:
        - idPattern: 'rabbitmq:vhost_{virtual_host}'
          instanceNamePattern: '{virtual_host}'
          iconPattern: server
          sources:
            - sourceType: Metrics
              condition: $prefix(messages_)
          requiredDimensions:
            - key: virtual_host

    - name: rabbitmq:queue
      displayName: Queue
      rules:
        - idPattern: 'rabbitmq:queue_{virtual_host}_{queue}'
          instanceNamePattern: '{queue}'
          iconPattern: queue
          sources:
            - sourceType: Metrics
              condition: $prefix(messages_)
          requiredDimensions:
            - key: queue
            - key: virtual_host

  relationships:
    - sources:
        - sourceType: Metrics
          condition: $prefix(messages_)
      fromType: rabbitmq:queue
      typeOfRelation: RUNS_ON
      toType: rabbitmq:vhost

After uploading, new metrics should cause entities to be created.

You can also use the monitored entities API to check that the relationship exists:

Making a request to https://lwp00649.dev.dynatracelabs.com/api/v2/entityTypes/rabbitmq:queue gives:

{
  "type": "rabbitmq:queue",
  "displayName": "Queue",
  "dimensionKey": "dt.entity.rabbitmq:queue",
  "entityLimitExceeded": false,
  "properties": [],
  "tags": "List",
  "managementZones": "List",
  "fromRelationships": [
    {
      "id": "runsOn",
      "toTypes": [
        "rabbitmq:vhost"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "toRelationships": []
}

In the next lesson we will customize the details screen of the virtual host so that we can show the queues that run on it.

activityList.name: Screens
activityList.content:
Screens

Dynatrace has a powerful feature called Unified Analysis Screens.
It allows one to declarative define a screen that shows metrics, topology, events, logs.
This is the same technology used for the product itself, and extension authors can use it to create custom screens.
You can find documentation here

We won't get indepth on screens, but here are some important points:

  1. For every entity type, you can optionally define the List and Details screens
  2. You can have charts, logs, relationships, properties and more on the screens
  3. Always try to define screens, it makes your extension easier to use and more powerful

Virtual Host Screen

Let's customize the Virtual Host Screen, to show some key metrics and add a list of queues running on the virtual host.

Add the screens element to extension.yaml:

screens:
  - entityType: rabbitmq:vhost

    # This is housekeeping, mandatory fields
    detailsSettings: 
      staticContent:
        showProblems: true
        showProperties: true
        showTags: true
        showGlobalFilter: true
        showAddTag: true

        breadcrumbs:
            - type: NOOP
            displayName: RabbitMQ
            - type: ENTITY_LIST_REF
            entityType: rabbitmq:vhost
            displayName: Virtual Hosts

      # Manually define the layout of the details page
      layout:
        autoGenerate: false
        cards:
          - key: vhost-metrics
            type: CHART_GROUP
          - key: vhost-queues
            type: ENTITIES_LIST

    chartsCards:
      - key: vhost-metrics
        mode: NORMAL
        numberOfVisibleCharts: 2
        displayName: Virtual Host Overview
        charts:
          # Define a chart with two metrics
          - displayName: Messages Published and Delivered
            visualizationType: GRAPH_CHART
            graphChartConfig:
              stacked: true
              metrics:
                - metricSelector: messages_deliver_get
                  visualization:
                    seriesType: COLUMN
                    displayName: Delivered
                - metricSelector: messages_publish
                  visualization:
                    seriesType: COLUMN
                    displayName: Published


          # Define a chart with 2 metrics
          - displayName: Messages Ready and Unacknowledged
            visualizationType: GRAPH_CHART
            graphChartConfig:
              stacked: true
              metrics:
                - metricSelector: messages_ready
                  visualization:
                    seriesType: COLUMN
                    displayName: Ready
                - metricSelector: messages_unacknowledged
                  visualization:
                    seriesType: COLUMN
                    displayName: Unacknowledged

    # List of entities
    entitiesListCards:
      - key: vhost-queues
        displayName: Queues
        pageSize: 5
        entitiesLimit: 500
        displayCharts: true
        enableDetailsExpandability: true
        numberOfVisibleCharts: 2
        displayIcons: true

        # How do we find the entities?
        entitySelectorTemplate: type(rabbitmq:queue),fromRelationships.runsOn($(entityConditions))

        # We can add charts to the list of entities
        charts:
          - displayName: Messages Ready
            visualizationType: GRAPH_CHART
            graphChartConfig:
              metrics:
                - metricSelector: messages_ready:splitBy()
                  visualization:
                    themeColor: TURQUOISE
                    seriesType: COLUMN
                    displayName: Ready
          - displayName: Messags Publish
            visualizationType: GRAPH_CHART
            graphChartConfig:
              metrics:
                - metricSelector: messages_publish:splitBy()
                  visualization:
                    themeColor: ORANGE
                    seriesType: AREA
                    displayName: Published

This definition produces the following screen:

Generating screens is made much easier if oyu use the VSCode extension autocomplete features.
It takes some time to get used to the syntax, but the effort is worth it.

name: Resources
content:
Resources

Links

  • Python SDK Documentation
  • Troubleshooting Python Extensions
  • Extensions team on slack
  • VSCode Extension
  • This training

Python Extensions

Some python extensions on the Hub, you can download and look at the code:

  • Anypoint MQ
  • Mulesoft Cloudhub
  • Citrix Desktops
  • Tibco EMS
  • Salesforce Event Streaming
  • Filesystem Monitoring
  • Elasticsearch

name: Extras
content:
Extras

On this bonus chapter, we will explore some of the exclusive features of the Python EF2 SDK.
These were not present in EF1, so it doesn't necessarily apply to a migration, but can make an extension nicer to use and code.

activityList.name: Scheduling methods and self monitoring
activityList.content:
Scheduling methods and self monitoring

Scheduling

As we've explored before, the query method still exists in EF2, but there is nothing special about this method.
From the SDK point of view, it is just a method that happens to be scheduled to run every 60 seconds.

You can also schedule your own methods to run at whatever frequency you prefer.

So we could modify the code, and instead of counting the number of executions, we can schedule a method with a specific time interval.

This is how the code can look like when using the schedule method:

import re
from typing import Dict
from datetime import timedelta

from dynatrace_extension import Extension
from dynatrace_extension.sdk.extension import DtEventType

from .rabbitmq_api import RabbitMQClient


class RabbitMQExtension(Extension):

    def initialize(self, **kwargs):

        endpoints = self.activation_config.get("endpoints")
        for endpoint in endpoints:
            frequency = endpoint.get("frequency", 1)

            # Schedule the monitor method to be run every <frequency> minutes
            # We also pass the endpoint as a parameter to this method
            self.schedule(self.monitor, timedelta(minutes=frequency), (endpoint,))


    def monitor(self, endpoint: Dict):
         # Step 1 - Get configuration parameters from the UI
        node_address = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_node", "")
        username = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
        password = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")
        queues_include = endpoint.get("queues_include", ".*").split("/n")

        # This is a check, we are trying to connect to RabbitMQ
        rabbit = RabbitMQClient(node_address, username, password, logger=self.logger)
        try:
            _ = rabbit.cluster
            self.logger.info(f"Successfully connected to {node_address}")
        except Exception as e:
            error_message = f"Could not connect to RabbitMQ node {node_address}"
            self.report_dt_event(DtEventType.ERROR_EVENT, error_message)
            self.logger.error(error_message)
            raise Exception(error_message) from e

        # Report the queue metrics
        for queue in rabbit.queues:
            self.logger.info(f"Checking queue '{queue.name}'")
            monitor = False

            for pattern in queues_include:
                if pattern and re.match(pattern, queue.name):
                    self.logger.info(f"Adding queue '{queue.name}' because it matched the pattern '{pattern}'")
                    monitor = True

            if monitor:
                self.report_metric("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})



def main():
    RabbitMQExtension().run()



if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

The main differences are:

  1. We remove the query method, we don't need anything to be scheduled every 60 seconds
  2. We add a new method called monitor, which takes an endpoint as a parameter, this method can have any name.
  3. We schedule this method to run every frequency minutes, and we pass the endpoint as a parameter to this method

Note that you can schedule methods with any custom frequency, you are no longer tied to running things every minute.

Self monitoring

Python extensions report some self monitoring metrics that might be useful when troubleshooting an extension

They are:

  • sfm:datasource.python.execution.count - The number of calls for each scheduled method.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.execution.exception.count - The number of raised exceptions for each scheduled method.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.execution.ok.count - The number of successful executions for each scheduled method.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.execution.time - How long each scheduled method took to run.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.execution.timeout.count - How many times a scheduled method took longer than it's interval to run.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.execution.total.count - The total number of executions of a callback since the extension started.
  • dsfm:datasource.python.threads - How many threads are currently running in the extension.

The number of threads is useful to know if you are running into performance issues:

It is also easy to spot methods that take too long to run:

There is also a self monitoring extension that comes with a handy dashboard and metrics:

activityList.name: Fastchecks
activityList.content:
Fastchecks

When running from an Activegate, there is one extra step that is done before an extension is assigned.

The EEC runs a fastcheck to determine if the extension can run on the Activegate.

As a developer, you can optionally define a method called fastcheck that will be called before the extension is assigned to an Activegate.
In this method you can test for instance if this AG can collect to the RabbitMQ, and raise an exception if it cannot.

We can change our extension to make use of the fastcheck:

import re
from typing import Dict
from datetime import timedelta

from dynatrace_extension import Extension
from dynatrace_extension.sdk.communication import Status, StatusValue

from .rabbitmq_api import RabbitMQClient


class RabbitMQExtension(Extension):

    def initialize(self, **kwargs):

        endpoints = self.activation_config.get("endpoints")
        for endpoint in endpoints:
            frequency = endpoint.get("frequency", 1)

            # Schedule the monitor method to be run every <frequency> minutes
            # We also pass the endpoint as a parameter to this method
            self.schedule(self.monitor, timedelta(minutes=frequency), (endpoint,))

    def create_rabbitmq_client(self, endpoint: Dict) -> RabbitMQClient:
        node_address = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_node", "")
        username = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_username", "guest")
        password = endpoint.get("rabbitmq_password", "guest")
        return RabbitMQClient(node_address, username, password, logger=self.logger)

    def fastcheck(self) -> Status:
        for endpoint in self.activation_config.get("endpoints"):
            rabbit = self.create_rabbitmq_client(endpoint)
            try:
                _ = rabbit.cluster
                self.logger.info(f"Successfully connected to {rabbit.base_url}")
            except Exception as e:
                error_message = f"Could not connect to RabbitMQ node {rabbit.base_url}"
                self.logger.error(error_message)
                raise Exception(error_message) from e

                # Optionally, we could return something like:
                # return Status(StatusValue.ERROR, error_message)

        return Status(StatusValue.OK, "This AG can monitor RabbitMQ")


    def monitor(self, endpoint: Dict):
        queues_include = endpoint.get("queues_include", ".*").split("/n")
        rabbit = self.create_rabbitmq_client(endpoint)

        # Report the queue metrics
        for queue in rabbit.queues:
            self.logger.info(f"Checking queue '{queue.name}'")
            monitor = False

            for pattern in queues_include:
                if pattern and re.match(pattern, queue.name):
                    self.logger.info(f"Adding queue '{queue.name}' because it matched the pattern '{pattern}'")
                    monitor = True

            if monitor:
                self.report_metric("messages_ready",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_unacknowledged",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_ack",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_deliver_get",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_publish",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_redeliver",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})
                self.report_metric("messages_return",  queue.messages_ready, dimensions={"virtual_host": queue.vhost, "queue": queue.name})



def main():
    RabbitMQExtension().run()



if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

We can run the fastcheck with dt-sdk run --fastcheck

 dt-sdk run --fastcheck
Running: C:\Program Files\Python310\python.exe -m rabbitmq_extension --activationconfig activation.json --fastcheck
2024-01-06 09:49:31,351 [INFO] api (MainThread): -----------------------------------------------------
2024-01-06 09:49:31,352 [INFO] api (MainThread): Starting <class '__main__.RabbitMQExtension'> , version: 1.1.1
2024-01-06 09:49:31,352 [INFO] api (MainThread): Running fastcheck for monitoring configuration ''
2024-01-06 09:49:31,552 [INFO] dynatrace_extension.sdk.extension (MainThread): Successfully connected to https://b-d9835915-0721-47f1-994c-b43c7b6dd800.mq.us-east-1.amazonaws.com
2024-01-06 09:49:31,552 [INFO] api (MainThread): Sending fastcheck status: {"status": "OK", "message": "This AG can monitor RabbitMQ"}
2024-01-06 09:49:31,553 [INFO] api (MainThread): send_status: '{"status": "OK", "message": "This AG can monitor RabbitMQ"}'

Fastchecks are an important part of AG extensions, and can give the user quick feedback when an AG cannot run an extension.
Fastcheks are supposed to be quick, they will timeout completely after 60 seconds, try to have them take 15 seconds or less to complete.
